body:
Comment 4: 
Building multiple 386 binary packages doesn't seem worth the cost.

32-bit processors are rare enough. People with weird/old processors can just build it
from source, or get it from elsewhere.

I would prefer to address the support problem: have the 32-bit binaries at start do a
CPU capability check and compare against what they were built for. If the CPU doesn't
support the instructions which will fail later, bail out early with a nice error message
("Not built with GO386=xxxx").

Even if we build three versions of the 32-bit packages, people will still be downloading
the wrong ones and bugging the mailing list & issue tracker, and redistributing the
wrong binaries elsewhere.
